title: Provides that people arrested in connection with a felony must submit a DNA sample
summary: Provides that people arrested in connection with a felony must submit a DNA sample.

       AN ACT to amend the executive law and the  criminal  procedure  law,  in
         relation to requiring individuals arrested in connection with a felony
         to submit a DNA sample

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Section 995 of the executive law is amended by adding a new
    2  subdivision 7-a to read as follows:

    4  ONE  OR MORE OF THE FOLLOWING FELONIES, OR AN ATTEMPT THEREOF WHERE SUCH

    4    S  2.  Subdivision 3 of section 995-c of the executive law, as amended
    5  by chapter 576 of the laws of 2004, is amended to read as follows:
    6    3. (A) Any designated offender subsequent to conviction and sentencing
    7  for a crime specified in subdivision seven of section nine hundred nine-
    8  ty-five of this article, shall be required to provide a sample appropri-
    9  ate for DNA testing to determine identification characteristics specific
   10  to such person and to be included in a state  DNA  identification  index
   11  pursuant to this article.
   12    (B)  A FELONY ARRESTEE SHALL BE REQUIRED TO PROVIDE A SAMPLE APPROPRI-
   13  ATE FOR DNA TESTING UPON HIS OR HER ARREST, UNLESS SUCH FELONY  ARRESTEE
   14  HAS PREVIOUSLY PROVIDED A SAMPLE THAT IS INCLUDED IN THE STATE DNA IDEN-
   15  TIFICATION INDEX.
   16    (C)  A PUBLIC SERVANT TO WHOSE CUSTODY A DESIGNATED OFFENDER OR FELONY
   17  ARRESTEE WHO HAS NOT YET PROVIDED A DNA SAMPLE HAS BEEN COMMITTED  SHALL
   18  SEEK AN ORDER OF THE COURT TO COLLECT SUCH SAMPLE IF THE OFFENDER, AFTER
   19  WRITTEN OR ORAL REQUEST, REFUSES TO PROVIDE SUCH SAMPLE.
   20    (D)  THE DETENTION, ARREST, INDICTMENT OR CONVICTION OF A PERSON BASED
   21  UPON DNA RECORDS CONTAINED IN THE STATE DNA IDENTIFICATION  INDEX  SHALL
   22  NOT BE INVALIDATED IF IT IS LATER DETERMINED THAT THE DIVISION OF CRIMI-
   23  NAL  JUSTICE  SERVICES  INADVERTENTLY,  BUT  IN GOOD FAITH, COLLECTED OR
   24  PLACED THE PERSON'S DNA SAMPLE IN THE INDEX.
   25    (E) THE COMMISSIONER OF CRIMINAL  JUSTICE  SERVICES  SHALL  PROMULGATE
   26  RULES AND REGULATIONS GOVERNING THE PERIODIC REVIEW OF THE DNA IDENTIFI-
   27  CATION INDEX TO DETERMINE WHETHER OR NOT THE INDEX CONTAINS DNA PROFILES
   28  THAT  SHOULD  NOT  BE  IN  THE  INDEX,  INCLUDING THE STEPS NECESSARY TO
   29  EXPUNGE ANY PROFILES WHICH THE DIVISION  OF  CRIMINAL  JUSTICE  SERVICES
   30  DETERMINES SHOULD NOT BE IN THE INDEX.
   31    S  3.  Subdivision 9 of section 995-c of the executive law, as amended
   32  by chapter 524 of the laws of 2002, is amended to read as follows:
   33    9. (a) Upon receipt of notification of a reversal or a  vacatur  of  a
   34  conviction,  or of the granting of a pardon pursuant to article two-A of
   35  this chapter, of an individual whose DNA record has been stored  in  the
   36  state  DNA  identification  index in accordance with this article by the
   37  division of criminal justice services, the DNA record shall be  expunged
   38  from  the  state DNA identification index, and such individual may apply
   39  to the court in which the judgment of conviction was originally  entered
   40  for  an  order  directing  the  expungement  of  any  DNA record and any
   41  samples, analyses, or other documents relating to  the  DNA  testing  of
   42  such  individual  in connection with the investigation or prosecution of
   43  the crime which resulted in the conviction that was reversed or  vacated
   44  or for which the pardon was granted. A copy of such application shall be
   45  served  on  the district attorney and an order directing expungement may
   46  be granted  if  the  court  finds  that  all  appeals  relating  to  the
   47  conviction  have  been  concluded;  that  such  individual  will  not be
   48  retried, or, if a retrial has occurred, the trier of fact has rendered a
   49  verdict of complete acquittal, and that expungement will  not  adversely
   50  affect  the investigation or prosecution of some other person or persons
   51  for the crime. The division shall,  by  rule  or  regulation,  prescribe
   52  procedures to ensure that the DNA record in the state DNA identification
   53  index,  and  any  samples, analyses, or other documents relating to such
   54  record, whether in the possession of the division, or any  law  enforce-
   55  ment  or  police  agency,  or any forensic DNA laboratory, including any
   56  duplicates or copies thereof, at the discretion of the possessor  there-
